Educators, families and community members are invited to participate in an online survey to gather feedback regarding education funding and other education issues in Arkansas.

Augenblick, Palaich and Associates (APA) is conducting a school finance study for the Arkansas House and Senate Education Committees. The Committees and APA believe that incorporating the perspective of educators and the community in Arkansas is essential to the study and will be gathering feedback on multiple study areas, including:
•What it means for students to be college and career ready when they graduate,
•Educational opportunities for students around the state,
•How well districts and charter systems in the state can attract and retain staff, and
•Education resources and funding in Arkansas, including the state education funding matrix and additional funding for specific student groups.

The survey is open to all educators and the general public until September 18th and can be found at the following link: apasurvey.link/arkfeedback

The United States Department of Agriculture (USDA) and the Arkansas Department of Education announced Wednesday, September 3 that all students will be provided free lunch and breakfast until December 31, 2020 as a response to COVID-19. The school needs all parents to complete and return the free lunch forms that were sent home with your students at the beginning of the year so that when USDA’s waiver on paid lunch ends, we can resume our free and reduced lunch program. Also, free and reduced lunch percentages are used to calculate supplemental Federal and State special funding that supports educational programs. We ask all parents to complete forms and return them as soon as possible. We do not know if the waiver will be extended to include the second semester.

Ok Dragon Fans...are you ready for a Blast from the Past?

This 1935 newspaper article was just sent to us from JCHS Alumnus Jacob Pumphrey, SAU Director of Mulerider Athletics Communications who received it from Great American Conference commissioner Will Prewitt!

It is the earliest Dragon Homecoming on record and the “Junction City eleven” clashed with Dubach on the local gridiron! The game was played in the afternoon at 2:30 immediately after the parade! Dubach beat the Dragons 6-0.

After the football game on that busy and festive November day, 85 years ago, our Lady Dragons Basketball Team played the Strong Tinymites...WOW...have you ever heard of the Tinymites? I guess Bulldogs is a better mascot!

#DragonHistory #BordertownProud
#85Years

JCSD-NECC IMPORTANT MESSAGE REGARDING SCHOOL RE-ENTRY:

Students will need to bring their own plastic reusable sealable water bottles. There will be no communal water fountains at school. At times during the day, a staff member will refill bottles for students, so they should come to school with a full bottle of water. We ask that students only bring water to deter sharing of flavored drinks. Clear bottles are best, but plastic is required. Students' names should clearly mark bottles. Please sanitize water bottles each day.

Cloth masks will also be provided for any student who doesn't have one. Please send students to school each day with a clean mask. Masks will only be removed when a teacher gives the students the okay. More information on masks will be released this week. Facemasks with political or offensive language or images are prohibited. Student handbooks address unacceptable language and images.

Changes to school arrival and dismissal will be communicated later this week.

Junction City School District

Class of 2020:

Food service:
Thursday will be the last day of food provision by the district. Friday is the last day of the school year.

Material return:

Retiring teacher recognized:
Teresa Matochik, Junction City Elementary principal, will retire this year after 24 years with the JCSD. She was previously a Kindergarten and elementary teacher and the Special Programs Director for the district.
